questions.text:
A 6-month old baby was brought to the clinic with the following finding.



Which among the following statements is incorrect regarding the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Oral propranolol can be used for treating this condition
Most common orbital tumor of children.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) More common in boys

 

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Capillary Hemangioma.

Description
  • Most common orbital tumor in children (Option D)
  • More common in girls than boys (3:2 ratio) (Option A)

Onset & Growth
  • Visible at birth in about one-third of cases
  • Rapid growth phase in the first 6 months
  • ~75% regress by 7 years old spontaneously (Option B)

Appearance
  • Red, raised nodular mass ("strawberry nevus")
  • Deep orbital mass: proptosis and globe displacement

Histopathology
  • Lobules of plump endothelial cells separated by fibrous septa

 

Management
  • Only done for complicated cases (affecting vision loss, systemic,etc.) and for cosmetic indications.
  • Oral Propranolol (Option C)
  • Intralesional corticosteroid
  • Radiotherapy/Cryotherapy
  • Surgery

 

Eyelid Tumors:

Benign Tumors

Papilloma
  • Most common benign tumor arising from surface epithelium

Xanthelasma
  • Middle aged woman, lipid deposits present within histiocytes

Hemangioma
  • Capillary & Cavernous hemangioma

Neurofibroma
  • Variant called Plexiform neurofibroma:
  • S-shaped appearance
  • Bag of worms feel on palpation

Keratoacanthoma
  • Non-pigmented protrusion with keratin filled central crater

Naevi
  • Congenital naevi ; Acquired naevi

 

 

Pre-Malignant Tumors

Actinic keratosis
  • Over sun-exposed areas

Xeroderma pigmentosum

  • Defective nucleotide excision repair

Malignant Tumors

Basal cell cancer
  • Most common malignant tumor of eyelid
  • Most common site: lower lid > medial canthus

Squamous cell cancer
  • 2nd most common malignant tumor of eyelid

Sebaceous gland carcinoma
  • Recurrence - common

Malignant melanoma
  • Most common type: superficial spreading type
  • Worst prognosis type: Nodular melanoma

questions.text:
Match the image with the condition:


	
		
			
			Image
			
			
			Condition
			
		
		
			
			a.  Chronic painless swelling

			
			
			
			1. Stye
			
		
		
			
			b. Acute painful swelling 

			
			
			
			2. Chalazion
			
		
		
			
			c. Acute painful Swelling 

			
			
			
			3. Hordeolum Internum
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) a-2,b-3,c-1

 

Explanation:

 

Condition

Definition & Features

Treatment

Hordeolum externum (Stye)
  • Acute suppurative painful inflammation of a lash follicle and associated glands of Zeis or Moll.
  • Most common causative organism - Staphylococcus aureus.
  • Symptoms: Acute pain with swelling on the anterior lid margin, watering and photophobia.

 
  • Hot compresses 2-3 times daily.
  • Evacuate pus by epilating involved cilia when pus point forms.
  • Rarely, surgical incision for large abscess.
  • Antibiotic eye drops and ointment.
  • Systemic anti-inflammatory and analgesics.
  • Systemic antibiotics for early infection control.
  • Identify and treat predisposing conditions in recurrent cases.

Hordeolum Internum
  • Acute Suppurative painful inflammation of the meibomian gland with duct blockage.


 
  • Similar to external hordeolum treatment.
  • Drain pus by a vertical incision from the tarsal conjunctiva when pus forms.

Chalazion
  • Chronic non-infective lipogranulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland.
  • Painless swelling of the eyelid, mild heaviness, blurred vision.
  • Nodule is present slightly away from the lid margin.
  • Malignant change into meibomian gland adenocarcinoma may be seen in elderly.
  • Conservative treatment: Hot fomentation, topical antibiotics, oral anti-inflammatory drugs.
  • Intralesional steroid injection (triamcinolone).
  • Incision (vertical on the conjunctival side, and horizontal on skin side), and curettage for conventional treatment.
  • Diathermy for marginal chalazion.
  • Oral tetracycline as prophylaxis in recurrent cases, especially with acne rosacea or seborrhoeic dermatitis.

questions.text: Which is the most common organism causing bacterial blepharitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Staphylococci

 

Explanation:

Staphylococci is the most common organism causing bacterial blepharitis

 

Bacterial blepharitis:

Definition

Chronic infection of the anterior part of the lid margin

Synonyms

  • Chronic anterior blepharitis
  • Staphylococcal blepharitis

Causative Organisms
  • Most commonly Staphylococci (coagulase positive)
  • Rarely Streptococci, Propionibacterium acnes, and Moraxella

Clinical Features
  • Chronic irritation
  • Itching
  • Mild lacrimation
  • Gluing of cilia
  • Mild photophobia
  • Yellow crusts at the root of cilia
  • Small ulcers that bleed easily when crusts are removed
  • Red, thickened lid margins with dilated blood vessels
  • Mild papillary conjunctivitis and conjunctival hyperemia

Treatment
  • Lid Hygiene:
    • Warm compresses
    • Cotton buds dipped in dilute baby shampoo or 3% sodium bicarbonate solution
    • Avoid touching
  • Antibiotics
  • Topical Steroids
  • Ocular Lubricants

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl has been having difficulty opening her left eye since birth. An image is given below. What is the condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ankyloblepharon

 

Explanation:

The scenario is of adhesion of upper and lower lid - ankyloblepharon

 

Condition

Definition

Etiology

Symblepharon

Palpebral and bulbar conjunctiva adhesions.
  • Healing of raw surfaces on the palpebral and bulbar conjunctiva.
  • Causes: Thermal or chemical burns, membranous conjunctivitis, injuries, conjunctival ulcerations, ocular pemphigus, Stevens-Johnson syndrome.

Ankyloblepharon

Adhesions between the margins of the upper and lower eyelids.
  • Congenital anomaly.
  • Acquired adhesions after healing of chemical burns, thermal burns, ulcers, and traumatic wounds of the lid margins.
  • Often associated with symblepharon.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with hypothyroidism is now complaining of loss of eyelashes. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Madarosis

 

Explanation:

The scenario is of loss of eyelashes (madarosis) secondary to hypothyroidism

 

Condition

Definition

Local Causes

Systemic Causes

Madarosis (Option A)

Partial or complete loss of eyelashes or eyebrows.
  • Chronic blepharitis
  • Cicatrizing conjunctivitis
  • Complications from cryotherapy, radiotherapy, or surgery for eyelid lesions
  • Alopecia
  • Psoriasis
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Leprosy
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Acquired syphilis

Poliosis (Option B)

Greying of eyelashes and eyebrows.
  • Chronic anterior blepharitis
  • Sympathetic ophthalmitis
  • Idiopathic uveitis
  • Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada syndrome
  • Waardenburg syndrome
  • Vitiligo
  • Marfan syndrome
  • Tuberous sclerosis

 

Tylosis (Option C) - thickening and scarring of the lid margin, a complication of long-standing bacterial blepharitis

questions.text: A neonatologist has noted the following finding in a newborn baby. What is the condition called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Distichiasis

 

Explanation:

  • The case is of distichiasis - extra eyelash row

 

Eyelash rubbing the cornea can happen in:

  • Trichiasis - Inward misdirection of lashes with the normal position of the lid margin (Option A ruled out)

  • Pseudotrichiasis - Inward turning of lashes along with the lid margin (Option B ruled out)
  • Distichiasis - Extra row of eyelash (Option C)

Clinical features
  • Foreign body sensation
  • Photophobia
  • Irritation
  • Pain
  • Lacrimation
  • Reflex blepharospasm and photophobia (if the cornea is abraded)
  • Conjunctival congestion

Complications
  • Recurrent corneal abrasions
  • Superficial corneal opacities
  • Corneal vascularization
  • Non-healing corneal ulcer

Treatment
  • Epilation
  • Electrolysis
  • Cryoepilation
  • Surgical correction

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presents with complaints of epiphora. On examination, there is an eversion of the punctum noted. Which among the following is incorrect regarding the type of ectropion seen in this patient?

choices.text: Age-related changes are implicated in etiopathogenesis
Starts from lateral eyelid and progresses medially

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Starts from lateral eyelid and progresses medially

 

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario is indicative of involutional ectropion.

 

Involutional ectropion:

  • Most common form (Option A)
  • Caused by age-related laxity of lower eyelid structures. (Option C)
  • It usually begins medially and extends laterally. (Option D)
  • Progression leads to: Conjunctival inflammation, Keratinization, Lagophthalmos (Option B)

 

Type of Ectropion

Description

Causes

Clinical Features

Treatment

Involutional Ectropion
  • Most common; age-related
  • Horizontal laxity
  • Canthal tendon laxity
  • Epiphora
  • Tarsal thinning
  • Lagophthalmos
  • Medial conjunctivoplasty for mild cases.
  • Horizontal lid shortening for moderate cases.
  • Byron Smith's modified Kuhnt-Szymanowski operation for severe cases.
  • Lateral tarsal strip technique for generalized ectropion.

Cicatricial Ectropion
  • Scarring of anterior lamella
  • Trauma/surgery
  • Scarring conditions (e.g., blepharitis)
  • Scarring
  • Skin fibrosis
  • Mild cases: V-Y operation.
  • Mild to moderate cases: Z-plasty (Elschnig's operation).
  • Severe cases: Excision of scar tissue and full-thickness skin grafting.

Paralytic Ectropion
  • Facial nerve palsy (Bell’s)
  • Bell’s palsy
  • Trauma/surgery
  • Exposure keratopathy
  • Temporary measures: Topical lubricants, eyelid taping, suture tarsorrhaphy.
  • Permanent measures (if needed): Horizontal lid tightening with/without middle lamellar buttress, palpebral sling operation.

Mechanical Ectropion
  • Mass or lesion pushing eyelid
  • Tumors
  • Conjunctival growths
  • Eyelid displacement
  • Conjunctival chemosis
  • Treat the underlying mechanical causes.

Congenital Ectropion
  • Present at birth
  • Tarsal plate atrophy
  • Down syndrome
  • Associated eyelid malformation
  • Mild cases may not require treatment.
  • Moderate or severe cases: Horizontal lid tightening and full-thickness skin graft.


 

Grading of Ectropion:

 

GRADE

FEATURE

0

Normal eyelid appearance and function

I

Only punctum is everted

II

Lid margin everted and palpebral conjunctiva visible

III

Fornix is also visible

questions.text:
Match the following types of entropion with their correct pair

 


	
		
			
			1) Mechanical entropion
			
			
			A) Trachoma
			
		
		
			
			2) Cicatricial entropion
			
			
			B) Phthisis bulbi
			
		
		
			
			3) Congenital entropion
			
			
			C) Senile entropion
			
		
		
			
			4) Involutional entropion
			
			
			D) Most commonly involves lower eyelid
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1-B, 2-A, 3-D, 4-C

 

Explanation:

 

1) Mechanical entropion

B) Phthisis bulbi

2) Cicatricial entropion

A) Trachoma

3) Congenital entropion

D) Most commonly involves lower eyelid

4) Involutional entropion

C) Senile entropion

 

Types of Entropion:

Type

Description

Etiology

1) Congenital Entropion

Present since birth, more common in the lower eyelid

  • Lower Eyelid: Improper development of lower lid retractors.
  • Upper Eyelid: Mechanical effects due to microphthalmos.

2) Cicatricial Entropion

Commonly involves the upper eyelid.



 
  • Common causes: Trachoma, chemical burns, pemphigus, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, symblepharon.

3) Senile (Involutional) Entropion

Affects the lower eyelid in elderly individuals.
  • Horizontal lid laxity
  • Vertical lid instability
  • Overriding of pretarsal orbicularis.
  • Laxity of orbital septum

4) Mechanical Entropion

Lack of support from the globe to the lids.
  • Occurs in conditions like phthisis bulbi, enophthalmos and after enucleation or evisceration operations.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male patient presents with the following ocular findings and complaints of watering and photophobia. On examination, there are signs of minimal horizontal lid laxity. Which of the following surgical procedures would be the most appropriate for a long-term correction of his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Weis procedure
 

Explanation:

  • The patient’s symptoms of watering and photophobia, along with the image of an inward-turned lower lid margin, suggest entropion.
  • The most appropriate surgical procedure for correcting entropion with minimal horizontal laxity is the Weis procedure.

 

Involutional Entropion:

Description and etiology
  • Usually seen in lower eyelid in elderly people
  • Horizontal lid laxity due to weakening of orbicularis muscle
  • Vertical lid instability due to weakening of capsulopalpebral fascia
  • Overriding of pretarsal orbicularis/Laxity of orbital septum

Clinical features
  • Foreign body sensation
  • Lacrimation
  • Photophobia
  • Horizontal lid laxity

Surgical Techniques

i. Transverse Suture and Everting Suture: (Option A)

  • Temporary cure (up to 18 months)
  • Suitable for very old patients

ii. Weis procedure: (Option B)

  • Long-term cure with minimal horizontal lid laxity

iii. Plication of Lower Lid Retractors (Jones Operation): (Option C)

  • Used in severe cases or after recurrence
  • Shortens lower lid retractors.

iv. Quickert Procedure: (Option D)

  • For cases with marked horizontal lid laxity
  • Combines horizontal lid shortening with Weis procedure

 

Grading of Entropion:

Grade-I

Only the posterior lid border is in-rolled

Grade-II

includes in-rolling up to the intermarginal strip

Grade-III

Whole lid margin including the anterior border is in-rolled

 

Complications include recurrent corneal abrasions, superficial corneal opacities, corneal vascularisation and even corneal ulceration.

questions.text: Which among the following structures is part of the anterior lamella of the eyelid?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Orbicularis oculi

 

Explanation:

  • The lid is made up of mainly thick connective tissue, which is called tarsal plate.
  • The eyelid is divided by a grey line into anterior and posterior lamella:
    • Anterior lamella structures include skin, subcutaneous tissue and orbicularis oculi (Option A).
    • Posterior lamella structures include tarsal plate (Option C) and conjunctiva (Option D).
  • The space between supraorbital margin and infraorbital margin is filled by a thin connective tissue known as orbital septum (Option B).

questions.text: All are causes of ipsilateral pseudoptosis except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lid retraction

 

Explanation:

Pseudoptosis: Apparent drooping of eyelid, unrelated to neurological or muscular abnormalities.

 

Causes of pseudoptosis:

Ipsilateral pseudoptosis

Contralateral pseudoptosis
  • Microphthalmos
  • Enophthalmos (Option A)
  • Phthisis bulbi (Option D)
  • Hypotropia (Option C)
  • Dermatochalasis
  • Eyelid retraction (Option B)
  • High myopia
  • Proptosis

questions.text: Which of the following measurements is considered indicative of moderate ptosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 3 mm droop

 

Explanation:

Measurement of the degree of Ptosis:

 

  • In unilateral cases, the difference in the vertical height of the palpebral fissures on the two sides indicates the degree of ptosis.

 

  • In bilateral cases, measure the amount of cornea covered by the upper lid and subtract 2mm.

 

Ptosis grading

 

Mild Ptosis

2mm droop

Moderate Ptosis

3mm droop

Severe Ptosis

4mm droop

 

Margin reflex distance (MRD)

  • MRD 1: Distance between the upper lid margins and corneal light reflex. The normal value is 4-4.5mm.
  • MRD 2: Distance between the pupillary reflex in the centre to the lower lid margin. Normal values 5 - 5.5mm.

questions.text: Which muscle is most commonly affected in congenital ptosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Levator palpebrae superioris

Explanation:

Congenital Ptosis:

  • Associated with congenital weakness or maldevelopment of the levator palpebrae superioris (LPS) muscle.
  • Congenital ptosis probably results from a failure of neuronal migration or development with muscular sequelae secondary to this. A minority of patients have a family history.

 

Characteristic features:

  • Drooping of one or both upper lids.
  • Lid crease is either diminished or absent.
  • Lid lag on downgaze due to tethering effect of abnormal LPS muscle.

 

Types of congenital ptosis:

 

1. Simple congenital ptosis:

  • Unilateral or bilateral
  • Non-progressive
  • No fluctuation: Unlike myogenic ptosis, congenital ptosis does not worsen throughout the day or improve with rest.

 

2. Congenital ptosis with associated weakness of superior rectus muscle.

 

3. Blepharophimosis syndrome:

  • Congenital ptosis
  • Blepharophimosis
  • Telecanthus
  • Epicanthus inversus.

 

4. Congenital synkinetic ptosis (Marcus Gunn jaw-winking ptosis)

  • Retraction of the ptotic lid with jaw movements due to stimulation of ipsilateral pterygoid muscle.
  • It occurs due to trigemino-oculomotor synkinesis. The pathophysiology of Marcus Gunn Jaw winking phenomenon is a congenital misdirection of mandibular branch of trigeminal nerve, i.e., this synkinetic movement results from a congenital aberrant connection between motor branches of the trigeminal nerve controlling muscles of mastication and superior division of the oculomotor nerve controlling the levator palpebrae superioris.

questions.text: Which of the following is a distinguishing feature of aponeurotic ptosis compared to other forms of ptosis?

choices.text: Presents with normal function of the levator muscle
Results from a neurological condition affecting the third cranial nerve
Usually involves a sudden onset of symptoms

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Presents with normal function of the levator muscle

 

Explanation:

Acquired Aponeurotic Ptosis: Develops due to defect of levator aponeurosis in the presence of a normal functioning muscle.

Also known as involutional ptosis.

 

It includes:

  • Senile Ptosis
  • Postoperative Ptosis
  • Ptosis associated with blepharochalasis.
  • Traumatic dehiscence or disinsertion of aponeurosis.

 

Accompanied by ocular motor dysfunction (Option A): Aponeurotic ptosis is not associated with ocular motor dysfunction, which is more common in neurological forms of ptosis.

 

Results from a neurological condition affecting the third cranial nerve (Option C): This describes ptosis due to cranial nerve III palsy, not aponeurotic ptosis.

 

Usually involves a sudden onset of symptoms (Option D): Aponeurotic ptosis generally has a gradual onset rather than sudden, distinguishing it from other types of ptosis that may present more abruptly.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with bilateral ptosis that worsens throughout the day, particularly in the evening, and improves with rest. She also complains of double vision and generalized fatigue. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Myasthenia gravis

 

Explanation:

Myasthenia gravis is a neuromuscular disorder characterized by weakness in voluntary muscles, which worsens with activity and improves with rest.

  • It often presents with ptosis, diplopia, and generalized muscle weakness.

 

Myogenic ptosis is caused by a myopathy of the levator muscle itself, or by impairment of transmission of impulses at the neuromuscular junction (neuromyopathic).

 

Acquired Myogenic Ptosis: Occurs due to acquired disorders of the LPS muscle or the myoneural junction.

Acquired myogenic ptosis occurs in myasthenia gravis, myotonic dystrophy and progressive external ophthalmoplegia

 

It is seen in conditions like:

  • Myasthenia gravis (M/C)
  • Dystrophia myotonica
  • Ocular myopathy
  • Oculopharyngeal muscular dystrophy
  • Thyrotoxicosis
  • Lambert Eaton myasthenic syndrome
  • Trauma to LPS muscle

 

Horner's Syndrome (Option A): Mild, constant ptosis which does not worsen with activity or improve with rest and no generalized fatigue or double vision.

 

Oculopharyngeal Muscular Dystrophy (OPMD) (Option C): Progressive, constant ptosis but no fluctuation or improvement with rest and no daily variation in symptoms.

 

Botulism (Option D): Sudden onset of ptosis.Symptoms do not improve with rest and not associated with daily fluctuation

questions.text: A 60-year old male, heavy smoker, presents with persistent shoulder pain radiating to arm for several months. He presents with the following ocular findings. A chest x-ray reveals mass at the apex of the left lung. Which of the following symptoms is most likely to accompany this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Anhydrosis and miosis

 

Explanation:

The given clinical vignette suggests that the patient most likely has Horner’s syndrome, which can result from a Pancoast tumor at the apex of the lung. This tumor can compress the sympathetic nerves, leading to the classic triad of symptoms: ptosis, miosis (constricted pupil), and ipsilateral facial anhydrosis (lack of sweating).

 

Acquired Neurogenic Ptosis: Acquired ptosis with drooping of the upper eyelid caused by a disruption in the nerve supply to the muscles responsible for elevating the eyelid.

 

Causes:

  • Third Cranial (Oculomotor) Nerve Palsy: The third nerve can be damaged by trauma, ischemia, infection, tumor, or compression, causing ptosis and diplopia.Oculomotor nerve palsy causes ptosis as it supplies the levator palpebrae superioris muscle.

The ptotic eyelid can be elevated with a frontalis sling or levator aponeurosis advancement.

  • Horner's Syndrome: Involves a lesion in the sympathetic pathway, affecting the Müller’s muscle, leading to mild ptosis accompanied by miosis (pupil constriction) and anhydrosis (loss of sweating).
  • Ophthalmoplegic migraine
  • Multiple Sclerosis

 

Diagnosis:

  • Topical apraclonidine test is now considered the test of choice. Apraclonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist that also acts as a very weak alpha 1-adrenergic agonist; when topically applied in Horner’s syndrome, it causes dilation of the affected pupil and possibly lid elevation, without change to the normal pupil.

 

Dilated pupil (mydriasis) (Option A): Horner's syndrome is characterized by a constricted pupil (miosis) rather than a dilated pupil (mydriasis).

 

Contralateral ptosis (Option B): Horner's syndrome typically affects only one side of the face, so the ptosis is unilateral and not contralateral.

 

Ophthalmoplegia (Option D): Not typically associated with Horner's syndrome. The syndrome primarily affects the sympathetic pathway and does not directly involve the muscles that move the eye.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked ‘X’ in the given image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Tarsal plate

 

Explanation: The structure ‘X’ is the tarsal plate which belongs to the posterior lamella of the eyelid.

 

The eyelid is divided by a gray line into anterior and posterior lamella:

 

Anterior lamella

Posterior lamella
  • Skin
  • Subcutaneous tissue
  • Orbicularis oculi
  • Tarsal plate
